question: MM1ABC, decides to sail to Douglas on the Isle Of Man. During the sailing which callsign should he use?

answers.answer: MM1ABC/MM
MD1ABC/MM
M1ABC/MM
MM1ABC/M

question: Which one of the following is not a valid UK callsign?

answers.answer: MM1ABC/MM
2D1ABC/P
G5AB/M
M2ABC/MM

question: Which one of the following is forbidden by the licence?

answers.answer: Listening to amateurs on frequencies not allocated to UK amateurs.
Operating whilst in an aircraft.
Operating whilst driving.
Sending messages using codes.

question: The callsign GI0xxx belongs to an amateur in

answers.answer: Wales
Guernsey
Northern Ireland
England

question: When operating from a car it is recommended that you use the suffix

answers.answer: /P
/A
/M
/MM

question: When the station is operated from a temporary premises in the same country of the main station the call given on the first page of the licence will be used with

answers.answer: No suffix
The suffix /M
The suffix /P
The suffix /MM

question: An amateur station may not be established and used

answers.answer: In a moving vessel on a canal or a non-tidal waterway
In an aircraft
On a public service vehicle with the written permission of the owner of the vehicle
On the sea, provided it is within territorial waters

question: May a member of the UK Police Force operate an established amateur radio station?

answers.answer: Yes, for the purpose of passing messages on behalf of the UK Police Force during an operation or excercise coducted by the Police Force
No, but the Licensee may permit the use of the station in order to pass messages on the Officer's behalf
No, unless the Officer holds a current United Kingdom Amateur Radio License
Yes, the Officer may use the amateur radio station to pass any message

question: An amateur radio station may be used in times of emergency for sending messages

answers.answer: On behalf of User Services services
For any social occasion
Relating to the Armed Forces
On behlaf of the British Red Cross Society

question: Who may operate, unsupervised, the Station of a Full licence holder?

answers.answer: The licensee only.
Any licensed radio amateur from the UK.
Any licensed radio amateur from the UK and any other country.
The licensee, and any representative of a User Service.

question: Apart from the Licensee, an amateur radio station may be operated by

answers.answer: The Emergency County Planning Officer
A person who holds an Amateur Radio Certificate issued by the Secretary of State
An officer of the British Red Cross society
An officer delgated by the local Chief Constable

question: operating maritime mobile the use of the radio equipment must cease when instructed by

answers.answer: the Coast Guard
the vessel’s communication officer
the vessel’s master
none of the above

question: Where would you use your UK callsign and the suffix /MM?

answers.answer: On board a barge on the Leeds Liverpool canal.
In the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.
On board a ferry on Lake Geneva.
Mobile in Scotland.

question: On board a ship within coastal waters the suffix to be added to the callsign is

answers.answer: /A
/M
/MM
None required

question: You are operating using your own callsign and appropriate prefix under CEPT licensing in a Region 2 host country. You may:

answers.answer: operate only within the frequencies specified in the UK Schedule
transmit only within the frequencies specified in the UK Schedule, but listen on others permitted in Region 2
operate within the frequencies allowed to Region 2 licensed amateurs
only operate under the supervision of a host country licensed amateur

question: When operating in other countries which have signed CEPT Recommendation T/R 61-01 you must

answers.answer: Have a Reciprocal Licence
Be a temporary visitor and non-resident in the host country
Have an authorisation document from the host country
Have a supplementary document issued by your own Licensing Authority

question: The Amateur Licence authorises the Licensee to use a station for certain purposes. For which of the following is the licensee NOT authorised

answers.answer: Taking part in disaster relief exercises conducted by the British Red Cross
Taking part in disaster exercises conducted by any United Kingdom Fire and Rescue Service
Receiving lawful transmissions within the framework of the United Kingdom Frequency Allocation Table which the Amateur is not licensed to receive

Publicising the meetings of the local Church Youth Club, which is of interest to both parties11(1) The Licensee shall be permitted to use the Radio Equipment to discuss any topics ofmutual interest with other Amateurs, and to seek to receive and impart any information and any ideas. (The Licensee is also referred to note 7 which stipulates that such messages must not be of a menacing, gross and/or indecent or illegal character)

question: Is the holder of an Amateur Radio Licence permitted to use a secret code when communicating with another amateur station?

answers.answer: Yes, when helping in disaster relief
No, only recognised codes may be used and then only if they do not obscure the meaning of the Message
Yes, providing the callsigns are not sent in code
Yes, if the details are entered clearly in the log

question: Without specific authorisation, you may NOT record and retransmit Messages:

answers.answer: addressed to you from other amateurs, excluding their callsigns
addressed to you from other amateurs, including their callsigns
as part of the intermediate relaying of Messages to other licensed amateurs
using a mailbox or bulletin board run by you

question: A broadcast may be made to amateur stations in general provided that

answers.answer: It is an initial call
Communication is not established with any station
The information sent is of general interest
The information is intended for disaster relief purposes

question: The recordings which a radio amateur may not transmit include

answers.answer: Messages which are grossly indecent, of menacing or illegal character and/or are of pecuniary interest
Recordings of the station with which the radio amateur is in contact, callsigns having been deleted
Recordings of messages which are addressed to a specific station by the originating station but from which the originating station callsign has been deleted
Recordings of communications carried out in disaster relief operations by the authorities

question: The language used in messages exchanged between amateur radio stations

answers.answer: Must be in the National Language of the licensee
Must not be offensive, osbscene or indecent in any way
Can be in cipher, code or secret language provided the General Manager of the Local Post Office area has been notified
Must be spoken slowly and clearly using the recognised phonetic alphabet

question: If a Full Licensee whose callsign is M0QRZ is operating from temporary premises in Wales, it is suggested that at intervals of 15 minutes or more frequently during radio communication the operator should send

answers.answer: M0QRZ/A and adhering to the conditions of location as set out in the licence
MW0QRZ/A and adhering to the conditions of location as set out in the licence
MW/M0QRZ/P and adhering to the conditions of location as set out in the licence
M0QRZ/Wales and adhering to the conditions of location as set out in the licence

question: An Amateur Station log should be kept, if requested by the UK Licensing Authority. The log should be made available for inspection, at any reasonable time, by a person acting under the authority of

answers.answer: Ofcom
Home Office
Local Police Constabulary
Radiocommunications Agency

question: Any amateur station can be closed down at any time on the demand of any person acting on behalf of

answers.answer: The Police
The Secretary of State
Ministry of Defence
The County or local District Councils

question: The radio station established and used by the holder of an amateur radio licence MUST be equipped for reception on

answers.answer: The Frequency bands used in the schedule to the licence
The frequency or frequencies which are currently in use for sending
Frequencies used in disaster relief by the Red Cross, St John Ambulance Brigade and Police
At least one band in the frequency band 3 to 30MHz

question: If demanded by a person authorised by the Secretary of State to close down or restrict operation the licensee must comply

answers.answer: Immediately
Within 24 hours
Within 7 days
Within 28 days

question: The period of validity of an amateur transmitting licence is (current answer different from answer given on mark grid)

answers.answer: Six months
One year
Five years
Until it is revoked

question: Which one of the following frequency bands may not be used for international disaster communications?

answers.answer: One which is not specifically mentioned (i.e. permitted) on their Licence Certificate/Document
3.5 to 3.8 MHz.
7.0 to 7.1 MHz.

question: You have a real-time QSO on 2 metres with another Packet station which is out of range. This is made possible through:

answers.answer: Digipeating
Mailboxes
Bulletin Boards
Voice Repeater

question: Under the IARU band plans which one of the following is true?

answers.answer: SSB operation is permitted on all HF bands.
Contests are permitted on all HF bands.
Transmissions on satellite frequencies should be avoided for terrestrial contacts.
Transmission on beacon frequencies is permitted during contests.

question: Which one of the following is NOT true?

answers.answer: You can get a Special Event Station callsign to celebrate your birthday.
You can get a Special Event Station callsign to celebrate Marconi's birthday.
You could get a Special Event Station callsign to celebrate the 80th anniversary of the RSGB.
Some organisations have permanent Special Event Station callsigns.

question: Which of the following recommends that wideband modes should NOT be used on the 30m band?

answers.answer: RSGB
IARU
OFCOM
RAYNET

question: You wish to experiment listening to PSK31 transmissions on the 20 metre band, but don't have a copy of the band plan handy. Where would you expect to find PSK31 transmissions?

answers.answer: In the lower portion of the band.
In the mid-portion of the band.
In the higher portion of the band.
Anywhere within the band.

question: The frequency stability of a transmitter

answers.answer: Must remain within 1% over a period of 1 hour
Is not specified
Must remain within 1% over the period the transmitter is operating
Must be as good as the state of technical radio reasonably permits

question: Which of the following frequency bands is allocated to the amateur service on an exclusive basis?
The main purpose of the "Q" codes is to

answers.answer: Save time on telephony
Save time on telegraphy
Use in the station log
Use on station confirmation cards

question: When sending a CQ call in Morse the callsign of the station should be sent at a speed

answers.answer: At which the sender is prepared to receive a reply
Of 20 words per minute
At which the sender is prepared to receive a reply but not more tan 20 words per minute
Of 15 words per minute

question: The "Q" code to ask "who is calling me?" is

answers.answer: QSP
QRM
QSL
QRZ

question: The spelling of the word LIBRA using the recommended phonetic alphabet is

answers.answer: Love India Baker Roger Alpha
Lima India Bravo Romeo Alpha
Love India Bravo Roger Able
Lima Item Bravo Radio Alpha

question: Morse telegraphy by on-off keying without the use of a modulating frequency is designated by the symbols

answers.answer: A1A
F3E
A2A
F1A

question: DX Cluster networks:

answers.answer: occur when DX stations group together to make it easier for amateurs to collect multiple rare countries
is a system using Packet radio (or Internet) for spreading DX information to amateurs who are logged on
is a system using Packet radio similar to a 'net' on telephony
are not permitted without a Notice of Variation

question: The 'offset' of a 2 m repeater is:

answers.answer: the distance (in km) your station is from the repeater
the height (in metres) of the repeater's antenna
the difference between its transmit and receive frequencies
the frequency of its CTCSS tone, if any

question: You are listening to another amateur through a repeater, when the repeater goes silent for a minute or so, but you can still hear the amateur on the input frequency. This is most likely because:

answers.answer: the amateur has talked for too long and the repeater has 'timed out'
the repeater keeper is doing maintenance
the repeater needs a tone burst
the repeater needs a CTCSS tone

question: The purpose of a 2 metre repeater is to

answers.answer: Permit amateur operation without the use of callsigns
Provide communication for emergency purposes
Make possible VHF contacts over longer distances
Experiment with frequency shift techniques

question: The holder of an amateur radio licence wishes to make radio contactwith a station in another IARU region who is permitted to transmit on7.25MHz. The licensee is allowed to

answers.answer: Transmit and receive on 7.25MHz
Transmit briefly on 7.25MHz to request the station to move to a permitted part of the band
Listen to the station on 7.25MHz and transmit only within the permitted band
Transmit and receive only within the permitted band
